Harraz received his BSc in chemistry (1991) and MSc in physical chemistry (1997), Cairo University, Egypt, the PhD from the School of Energy Science, Kyoto university, Japan in 2003. He has awarded Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS) Postdoc Fellowship during 2003-2005 and Federation of Arab Scientific Research Councils Award for Outstanding Scientific Research in Nanotechnology in 2014. Graphical abstract The present review is focused on improving the battery capacity, reversibility, and cycle life of lithium/sodium ion batteries from the perspective of pre-lithiation/sodiation additives strategy. Lithium/Sodium-ion batteries (LIB/SIB) have attracted enormous attention as a promising electrochemical energy storage system due to their high energy density and long cycle life. One of the major hurdles is the initial irreversible capacity loss during the first few cycles owing to forming the solid electrolyte interphase layer (SEI). This process consumes a profusion of lithium/sodium, which reduces the overall energy density and cycle life. Thus, a suitable approach to compensate for the irreversible capacity loss must be developed to improve the energy density and cycle life. Pre-lithiation/sodiation is a widely accepted process to compensate for the irreversible capacity loss during the initial cycles. Various strategies such as physical, chemical, and electrochemical pre-lithiation/sodiation have been explored; however, these approaches add an extra step to the current manufacturing process. Alternative to these strategies, pre-lithiation/sodiation additives have attracted enormous attention due to their easy adaptability and compatibility with the current battery manufacturing process. In this review, we consolidate recent developments and emphasize the importance of using pre-lithiation/sodiation additives (anode and cathode) to overcome the irreversible capacity loss during the initial cycles in lithium/sodium-ion batteries. This review also addresses the technical and scientific challenges of using pre-lithiation/sodiation additives and offers the insights to boost the energy density and cycle life with their possible commercial exploration. The most important prerequisites for designing effective pre-lithiation/sodiation additives have been explored and the future directions have been discussed. Keywords Pre-lithiation/sodiation additives Solid electrolyte interphase Anode pre-lithiation/sodiation additives Cathode pre-lithiation/sodiation additives Coulombic efficiency 1 Introduction Rechargeable lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) dominate the energy storage market in sectors ranging from portable electronics to electric vehicles [1,2]. Research and development in battery chemistries alternative to Li-ion are also rapidly growing, considering the high cost and limited abundance of lithium [3–5]. For example, rechargeable Na-ion batteries (SIBs) are the most promising alternative in large-scale energy storage, where cost efficiency and sustainability are relatively more important than energy density [6,7]. Considering the similar charge storage mechanism and materials characteristics in LIBs and SIBs, it is unsurprising that both technologies share a similar capacity fading mechanism. One is associated with forming solid electrolyte interphase (SEI), causing irreversible loss of active ions in the first cycle. Commercial LIB/SIB devices work on the “rocking chair” mechanism using lithiated/sodiated metal oxides and graphite/hard carbon as cathode and anode, respectively [8–10]. Irrespective of the electrode materials, for both the LIBs and SIBs, a large irreversible capacity loss is observed during the initial cell operation due to the irreversible consumption of the metal ions. This irreversible capacity loss can be attributed to the three major processes/factors, (i) active metal ion consumption during the SEI formation, (ii) phase transition of the cathode, and (iii) the defects on the anode. In addition, the coating defects including non-uniform coating, pinholes, agglomerates, etc. also accelerate the irreversible capacity fading [11]. During the first charging process, the Li+/Na+ ions move from lithiated/sodiated metal oxides to graphite/hard carbon anode [12,13]. Since the anode operating voltage is usually beyond the electrochemical stability window of the electrolyte, the electrolyte reacts with the active electron on the conducting anode surface and is reduced to inorganic/organic insulating salts of lithium or sodium on the graphite or hard carbon anode surface, forming a SEI. While discharging, some Li+/Na+ ions are trapped in the graphite/hard carbon electrode resulting in poor initial coulombic efficiency (ICE) and the energy density of LIBs/SIBs is sacrificed considerably. This issue is even more serious with the alternative high-capacity anodes (Si, Sn, etc.) working via alloying/dealloying mechanism involving huge volume change during the process. During the volume expansion, freshly exposed active materials continuously react with electrolytes to form thick SEI, resulting in significant capacity loss and low ICE [14,15]. This process also utilizes large amount of lithium ion until a stable SEI is formed [16,17]. Consequently, the usable lithium-ion capacity and overall energy density of LIBs using would be significantly decreased. With limited lithium reservoir at the cathode, this type of initial capacity loss will affect the overall energy density of the device. Although these irreversible capacity losses are inevitable, it is necessary to supply extra lithium sources into the batteries in order to compensate this loss and recover the energy density. On the other hand, in the full-cell configuration, all the reversibly intercalated/deintercalated lithium ions are from the cathodes (LCO, LFP and NMC), which are limited. The theoretical capacity of these cathodes is usually less than the state-of-the-art anode materials. Furthermore, a certain extent of the released metal ions during charging cannot be reinserted upon discharge, which constitutes to the first cycle irreversible capacity loss (ICL). This first cycle loss can arise due to (1) excess charge capacity caused by irreversible reactions with the electrolyte, (2) irreversible structural changes, particularly on the surface, which could include the formation of an SEI-type layer (cathode electrolyte interphase, CEI), and (3) slow kinetics for lithium intercalation. In case of nickel rich cathode, the ICL can be attributed to the collapse of the interlayer spacing induced by oxidation of Ni2+ to Ni3+ or to Ni4+. On the other hand, layered oxide cathodes experience chemical instability resulting in a tendency to lose oxygen from the lattice at deep charge voltages (due to an overlap of the metal 3d band with the top of the oxygen 2p band [18–20]), which increases ICL significantly. The first-cycle irreversible capacity loss can be overcome by increasing the loading of active cathode materials, but this hampers the overall energy density of the device. It is essential to control the mass balancing of anode/cathodes to obtain a long-lasting device with stable performance. As the theoretical capacity of cathodes is usually low (200–300 mA h g−1), the initial irreversible capacity loss in the first cycle predominantly affects the long-term performance of the device. Thus, suppressing this irreversible capacity or compensating for this irreversible capacity loss to improve the first cycle coulombic efficiency of the devices is very important to realize stable reversible capacity. One of the most effective strategies to compensate for the irreversible capacity loss is the use of pre-lithiation/sodiation additives. Using pre-lithiation/sodiation additives provides an additional source of lithium/sodium, which helps pay for the irreversible loss during the first cycle. Pre- lithiation/sodiation can be applied at both the anodes and cathodes, depending on the potentials of lithiation/sodiation and de-lithiation/de-sodiation. The mechanism of the pre-lithiation/sodiation process in an ideal condition, assuming that the Li+/Na+ ion concentration in the cathodes is 100%, is schematically shown in Fig. 1 . In a full cell, the only source of active lithium/sodium is from the cathodes where Li+/Na+ ions travel to and fro during electrochemical charge/discharge. During the first charge, Li+/Na+ ions move from cathode to anode, during which SEI is formed at the anode caused by the electrolyte reduction, which leads to a large active Li+ loss. Assuming a small amount (40%) of Li+ from the cathodes is utilized for the initial capacity loss (formation of the SEI and side reaction), it remains 60% of active Li+/Na+ at the cathodes for the next cycles (Fig. 1a). In the presence of pre-lithiation/sodiation, we assigned 40% pre-Li+/Na+ as additives for simplicity (Fig. 1b). This irreversible capacity loss varies from 10%–20% for graphite and 20%–30% for alloying/conversion-based anode materials in LIB [16,17]. In the case of cathode pre-lithiation, the active Li+/Na+ loss is compensated by directly adding pre-lithiation/sodiation, which improves the Li+/Na+ reservoir. This Li+/Na+ from the additives can be extracted from the structure via anodic oxidation, which can be used to form the stable SEI, which leaves almost 100% active lithium/sodium at the cathodes. In the case of anode pre-lithiation, the additives are added to the anode, which uses the lithium to form a stable interface in the first few cycles (Fig. 1c). The loss of active Li+/Na+ ions also affects the consecutive cycle capacity, coulombic efficiency, and reversibility. Herein, the pre-lithiation/sodiation plays an important role in compensating for this irreversible Li+/Na+ loss. Pre-lithiation/sodiation can be broadly classified into four types: (a) chemical pre-lithiation/sodiation [21,22], (b) electrochemical pre-lithiation/sodiation [23–26], (c) direct contact with lithium/sodium [27–29], and (d) use of additives [30–33]. 1.1 Pre-lithiation approaches In chemical pre-lithiation, it is possible to achieve an effective pre-lithiation of the negative electrode by using optimized reaction conditions (concentration, reaction duration, etc.). Additionally, the reaction time can adjust the amount of pre-lithiation relatively well. However, the utilized chemicals and reaction conditions seem problematic to handle due to their high reactivity, resulting in safety concerns. Significantly, the amalgamation into a commercial production process for active material, electrode, and cell fabrication for LIBs is hampered by these facts. Electrochemical pre-lithiation enables the possibility of performing pre-lithiation in a well-controlled manner, i.e., the degree of pre-lithiation can be easily controlled by varying the applied voltage and duration. Electrochemical pre-lithiation generally takes a lower current to promote uniform Li-doping and sometimes undergoes multiple cycling. One of the major drawbacks is that excessive amounts of lithiation to the electrode may lead to its structural degradation. Excessive lithiation or over lithiation can result in lithium plating on the electrode surface. Also, the electrochemically pre-lithiated cell requires re-assembling after pre-lithiation, resulting in an additional manufacturing step. In the case of direct contact mode of pre-lithiation, the choice of lithium source plays a critical role in the overall performance. Thick Li metal foils (∼100–200 µm) are typically much cheaper than stabilized lithium metal powder (SLMP) and thin Li metal foils (<100 µm). However, the pre-lithiation process was reported to be much quicker with thin Li metal foil due to its fast kinetics. The degree of pre-lithiation can be controlled well with SLMP and poorly with relatively thick Li metal foil. Implementing direct contact pre-lithiation into the manufacturing process of commercial battery cells using thick Li metal foil seems complicated because excess Li metal, which is not used for pre-lithiation, must be removed from the surface before cell assembly. In contrast, thin Li metal foil and SLMP have the benefits of consuming the entire Li metal during pre-lithiation, enabling the cell to be assembled instantaneously. Nevertheless, the high cost of SLMP hinders its practical implementation. One of the major challenges of direct contact pre-lithiation is that the unreacted Li+ ions that lose the electronic conductivity (dead Li) gather around the electrode interfaces to hinder the charge-transfer reactions by blocking the electron channels. This causes only little Li utilization from the pre-lithiation source in the direct contact mode. In contrast to direct contact approach, Yue et al. demonstrated that vacuum thermal evaporation (VTE) method to deposit sacrificial lithium film on anode is a much effective direct contact technique to maximize the conformal contact at the interface [34,35]. The improved conformal contact promotes the reaction kinetics and reduces the local current density to stabilize the electron channels, thereby maximizing the Li utilization. With a 4 µm thick VTE deposited Li film on graphite anode, Li utilization as high as 91% was demonstrated. Also, the formation of electrically insulating raw electrolyte interface (REI) formed on the anode and pre-lithiation source have a significant impact on the Li utilization in the direct contact mode. Yue et al. further demonstrated that when dimethyl carbonate (DMC) was used as electrolyte in the contact pre-lithiation process, a stable REI could be formed. With a VTE deposited 2 µm thick Li sacrificial film on graphite anode and DMC solvent, Li utilization as high as ∼92.8% was demonstrated. The VTE is a highly promising approach and requires a significant research effort for the large-scale implementation. Thus, it is very critical to develop an efficient and economical approach that can be effortlessly implemented into the manufacturing process of commercial cells. Another most important and efficient way to compensate for the irreversible capacity loss is using pre-lithiation additives. The use of the pre-lithiation additives can pay for the irreversible capacity loss by providing an excess of lithium during the first cycle. Pre-lithiation additives can be broadly classified into two types (i.e., anode and cathode pre-lithiation additives), depending on the voltage at which they can release the excess lithium ions. Pre-lithiation additives can be directly incorporated in the current state-of-art battery manufacturing process, making it a viable option compared to other pre-lithiation approaches. In the case of cathode pre-lithiation, pre-lithiation additives such as Li3N, LiN3, Li6CoO4, Li5FeO4, Li2MoO3, and Li2O/M (M = Fe, Co, Mn) having high specific capacity are added to the cathodes, which increase the Li+ ion concentration at the cathodes (140%, assuming 40% is derived from the pre-lithiation additives). This additional source of Li+ can be used up during the first cycle, leaving behind a sufficient amount of Li+ for consecutive cycles. In this way, the additives can compensate for the irreversible capacity loss during the first few cycles. In the case of anode pre-lithiation, lithium metal powder or lithiated materials are added to the anode, which can be utilized to form SEI and improve the coulombic efficiency for the first few cycles. However, due to their high reactivity, lithiated active materials are not compatible with polar processing solvents, in particular with aqueous processing. The available pre-lithiation additives are not stable in the air and thus require a controlled fabrication atmosphere. The search for air-stable additives has become one of the priorities for commercializing pre-lithiation additives. 1.2 Pre-sodiation approaches Similar to pre-lithiation, pre-sodiation can be broadly categorized into three types: (i) electrochemical pre-sodiation (ex-situ or in-situ), (ii) direct contact method (sodium metal powder, SMP), (iii) cathode pre-sodiation additives. In case of the electrochemical pre-sodiation, the cathode electrodes are first assembled with sodium metal and cycled at a specific current density. The degree of pre-sodiation can be easily controlled by varying the current density, time, and cycle number. After the initial process, the electrodes are disassembled and the anode electrode is re-assembled with a fresh cathode to build a full-cell SIB. This approach can achieve pre-sodiation of the anode in a well-controlled manner and the SEI layer can be modulated to achieve a relatively homogeneous and stable interphase. These approaches are constrained to coin cell testing in laboratory scale as multiple assembly/disassembly processes increase the process steps and costs which makes it difficult for large scale implementation. Direct contact method has been a potential alternative, wherein the SMP is directly coated on the electrode surface under a certain pressure to achieve the uniform pre-sodiation. In direct contact method, the degree of pre-sodiation can be controlled by tuning the reagent concentration and the applied pressure. Also, the process is relatively simple and spontaneous, which is advantageous as compared to the electrochemical pre-sodiation. Nevertheless, the mechanical contact with sodium metal suffers from thermal runway issues. Also, due to the high reactivity of sodium metal, pre-sodiation need to be processed in glove box with inert atmosphere, making the large-scale implementation unrealistic. Thus, it is very critical to develop an efficient and economical approach that can be effortlessly implemented into the manufacturing process of commercial cells. In this context, the use of pre-sodiation additives could be a simple and efficient way to compensate for the irreversible capacity loss. In this method, the pre-sodiation additive is added to the cathode material, where the additives undergo electrochemical oxidation to release Na+ ions to compensate the initial capacity loss for the formation of SEI on the anode surface. The use of pre-sodiation additive does not add any additional step in the current manufacturing process as the activation process takes place during the formation step of SEI. Similar to pre-lithiation additives, ideal pre-sodiation additives should meet the following requirements: (a) the de-sodiation potential of the additive reagent should lie within the operating voltage of the full cell; (b) they should possess high specific capacity; (c) the de-sodiation additive should not leave behind residual by-product which acts as a ‘dead volume’ effecting the overall energy density (d) they should be compatible with current industrial manufacturing process to ensure large scale implementation. Among various pre-sodiation strategies, the use of pre-sodiation additives offers a viable option due to their simple, effective, and easy adaptability in current industrial manufacturing process. So far, a number of potential pre-sodiation additives such as NaN3 [36], Na2O2 [37], Na2CO3 [38] etc. with high specific capacity have been investigated. The additional Na+ ions from the additives are used up during the first cycle, leaving behind a sufficient amount of Na+ for consecutive cycles. Nevertheless, the state-of-the-art pre-sodiation additives are not stable in the air and require a controlled fabrication atmosphere. Thus, the search for air-stable additives has become one of the priorities for commercializing pre-sodiation additives. Over the past few years, several critical reviews have been reported to summarize pre-lithiation progress and its importance. Holtstiege et al. reviewed the importance of the pre-lithiation strategy for energy storage technologies such as lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), sodium-ion batteries (SIB), lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries, Li-O2, and lithium-ion capacitor (LIC) [39]. Where, a comprehensive investigation of various pre-lithiation approaches/techniques and their commercial potential are highlighted. In another progress reported by Jin et al., they highlighted the importance of pre-lithiation for the next-generation practical LIBs. The origin of the huge initial active lithium loss of the anode and its effect on the performance of full cells are first illustrated [40]. Wang et al. summarized the advantages, challenges, and potential application scenarios of pre-lithiation approaches for largescale practical applications for next-generation high-energy-density LIBs [41]. Very recently, Dose et al. [42] and Ding et al. [43] highlighted the importance of cathode pre-lithiation additives for next-generation LIBs. Sun et al provided a mechanistic insight into the impact of pre-lithiation on the cycling stability of the full cells, the degree of pre-lithiation, and the stability of SEI [44]. Previous review articles have broadly focused on various pre-lithiation techniques and their influence on LIB performance. Herein we focus on the various factors in concern with the initial irreversible capacity loss and poor coulombic efficiency in both LIBs and SIBs and give a comprehensive overview on the strategy of using pre-lithiation/sodiation additives. We illustrate the unique advantages and key challenges of this strategy in compensating the irreversible capacity loss, improving coulombic efficiency and cell reversibility during cycling in both LIBs and SIBs. The different types and applicable scenarios of additives (e.g., pre-lithiation additives such as Li2.6Co0.4N, Li x Si-Li2O, Li3N, LiN3, Li6CoO4, Li5FeO4, Li2MoO3, and Li2O/M (M = Fe, Co, Mn) and pre-sodiation additives such as NaN3, Na2O2, Na2CO3, and Na2NiO2) are clarified and the specific issues when using such additives are proposed. The electrochemical properties of different additives, their utility and electrochemical performance in full cell LIBs and SIBs are summarized. In addition, a perspective on the designing of future pre-lithiation and pre-sodiation additives and their processing strategies to realize their possible industrial applications has been provided. Overall, the present review on improving the battery capacity, reversibility, and cycle life from the perspective of additive strategy should provide new understanding and reference ideas for related researchers. 2 Pre-lithiation additives 2.1 Anode pre-lithiation additives Lithium alloy materials have been adopted as the potential anode materials due to their high capacity. However, the significant volume change during cycling results in pulverization of the electrode material, which hinders its practical application [45–47]. Various lithium supplements have been extensively used, such as SLMP and thin lithium foils. However, the safety and high cost of lithium metal and chemical reactivity make it challenging to handle and adapt to the current industrial battery manufacturing processes. On the other hand, lithiated metal oxides or Si with better air stability have emerged as a potential anode additive. Different anode pre-lithiation additives and their detailed research progress will be introduced in this section. 2.1.1 Li2.6Co0.4N as an anode pre-lithiation additive The initial irreversible capacity of anode materials is quite large, leading to very low coulombic efficiency at the first cycle. Various structural and morphological modification strategies have been employed to improve the electrochemical performance, but the initial irreversible capacity of anodes remains too large for its practical application. Alternatively, Li2.6Co0.4N with the hexagonal structure has attracted enormous attention as an anode material with a high specific capacity over 760 mA h g−1. It shows high de-lithiation capacity but low lithiation capacity, making it a potential sacrificial additive (2Li2.6Co0.4N → 2.6Li+ + 2.6e− + N2↑ at 1.0 V) [48]. However, Li2.6Co0.4N itself cannot be directly used as an anode with high voltage cathodes (LiCoO2 and LiMn2O4) due to its low insertion and extraction capacity. This makes it a potential pre-lithiation additive, in which Li+ ions can be extracted from the structure via anodic oxidation in either chemical or electrochemical ways. Yang et al. first demonstrated the efficacy of Li2.6Co0.4N as a pre-lithiation additive for Sn-Sb alloy anode, which suppressed the volume change and provided excess lithium resulting in high capacity and significantly improved coulombic efficiency [49]. Further, the efficiency of Li2.6Co0.4N as a pre-lithiation additive was demonstrated with different anodes, such as SnSb0.14, SnO2, SnO, and SiO1.1, which showed high coulombic efficiency nearing 100% in the first cycle [50–52]. The Li2.6Co0.4N additive had influence in PEO-based polymer electrolyte with BaTiO3 filler which could stabilize Sn-Sb alloy anode [53–55]. Later, Liu et al. investigated the role of Li2.6Co0.4N in the Si-graphite composite to suppress the volume expansion and irreversible capacity loss of the Si anode [56]. The addition of Li-rich Li2.6Co0.4N greatly influenced the electrochemical properties with 100% coulombic efficiency. The above results suggest the importance of Li2.6Co0.4N as a promising anode additive to compensate for the irreversible capacity loss of high-capacity alloy-based anodes. Sun et al. investigated the role of lithiated Li2.6Co0.4N as additives for hard carbon-based material [57]. They found that Li2.6Co0.4N cannot be used as anode material, but the Li+ in Li2.6Co0.4N can act as a source of lithium to compensate for the irreversible capacity loss. A reversible capacity of 300 mA h g−1 with a coulombic efficiency of 66% was obtained for control samples. In contrast, the composite electrode showed a high reversible capacity of 438 mA h g−1 with 100% coulombic efficiency, as shown in Fig. 2 (a). To understand the used additive for practical application, they extended the study to a full cell using LiCoO2 as a cathode and hard carbon/Li2.6Co0.4N composite as an anode. The full cell delivered a high charge/discharge capacity of 525/438 mA h g−1 with a coulombic efficiency of 81%, which was higher than the control samples (51%) (Fig. 2b). The decomposition of Li2.6Co0.4N can provide additional Li+ ions along with the formation of N2 gases and residual material (Co), which can have an adverse effect on long-term cycling. The evolution of N2 gases inside a device can cause volume expansion, resulting in the thermal runway of the device. The presence of inactive residual by-products can add extra weight, decreasing the overall energy density of the device. Thus, to achieve a better stable electrochemical performance, the degree of pre-lithiation is the most critical parameter to be considered without hampering the pristine anode properties. Similarly, in another case, the effect of the pre-lithiation additive was investigated for disordered carbon and graphitic carbon. Further, Hanai et al. investigated the role of co-doping (with Cu, Ni, Fe) in Li2.6Co0.4N, which showed further improvement in the cyclic performance, as shown in Fig. 2(c). This enhanced performance can be attributed to the improved degree of Li extraction and interfacial compatibility with the electrolyte system. Further, the composite electrodes showed better capacity retention at a high current density, offering the better rate performance (Fig. 2d) [58]. In 2009, Liu et al. extended the use of Li2.6Co0.4N additive for natural graphite and found that 20 wt% of Li2.6Co0.4N could improve the coulombic efficiency from 69% to 100% [59]. Later the use of Li2.6Co0.4N was extended for TiP2O7 and LiTi2O4 anodes to develop a novel hybrid nanocomposite anode that was free from irreversible capacity loss and could achieve high electrochemical stability [60,61]. Using Li2.6Co0.4N as a pre-lithiation additive showed the improved initial coulombic efficiency, but the cyclic stability was poor. Although the degradation mechanism is not precise, the instability can arise due to the decomposition of the nitride involving evolution of gases and remaining residual inactive materials from the pre-lithiation additives. 2.1.2 LixSi as an anode and pre-lithiation agent Silicon is considered a potential anode material alternative to graphite due to its high theoretical capacity (4200 mA h g−1) and large abundance. However, the considerable volume (300%) changes of silicon during lithiation/de-lithiation and pulverization cause a fast irreversible capacity loss. Li x Si-Li2O has been successfully employed as a potential anode or a pre-lithiation additive to overcome this initial capacity loss. It possesses exceptional low potential (vs. Li/Li+), which is compatible with most anode materials such as graphite, Si, and Ge. Li x Si has a very high specific capacity (2000 mA h g−1 for Li4.4Si), requiring only a small quantity of pre-lithiation additives to compensate for the irreversible capacity loss. Another significant advantage of using pre-lithiation additives is the easy synthesis and adaptation to the current battery manufacturing process. Although Li x Si is an excellent pre-lithiation additive, its strong chemical reactivity in the atmosphere and the interaction with the solvent during the slurry preparation are the main obstacles to its general utilization. There are ways to address this issue, such as by using an artificial layer of protection to ensure rapid lithium-ion diffusion and not interfere with the electrode performance. A more effective method of artificially shielding these pre-lithiation additives (Li x Si) is thus required. The use of Li x Si-Li2O as a pre-lithiation additive was first proposed by Zhao et al. in 2016, a core-shell structure was synthesized where the reactive Li x Si core was covered with a dense Li2O layer [62]. The Li2O layer acts as an artificially shielding layer that is stable in the dry-air atmosphere, making it amenable to practical battery manufacturing. The synthesis of Li x Si-Li2O was carried out via a one-step thermal alloying process, as shown in Fig. 3 (b). The effect of the Li x Si-Li2O additive was studied for graphite and silicon anodes, which showed a remarkably improved coulombic efficiency of 94% and 100%, respectively. The Li+ extraction properties were studied via delithiating the samples to 1.0 V directly. Interestingly, no Li+ could be extracted from the Li x Si-Li2O nanoparticles (NPs) processed with N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) solvent; whereas small Li+ extraction could reach 300 mA h g−1 in DMC-based solvent. A high Li+ extraction capacity of 1200–1400 mA h g−1 could be achieved in dioxolane (DOL) and toluene, suggesting better compatibility. Li x Si-Li2O additive was stable with 91% capacity retention after one day of exposure to dry air. Li x Si particles react with the oxygen when treated with the proton-containing solvents (water/alcohol) and form a dense Li2O layer that protects the inner core from further oxidation over the long term in a dry-air atmosphere. In contrast, highly polar solvents such as NMP/organic carbonates weaken the Li2O layer, making them poor candidates for slurry preparation. Free electrons can attack the highly polar functional groups in Li x Si, acting as a nucleophile. Thus, choosing a suitable solvent is critical in obtaining maximum performance. In continuation of the previous work, the same group developed a surface modification technique to form a continuous dense coating consisting of LiF and Li alkyl carbonate via the reduction of 1-fluorodecane on the Li x Si surface [63]. Under ambient conditions, the coating works as a passivation layer and improves the performance in dry air. The modified Li x Si showed a remarkably high capacity of 2100 mA h g−1 with capacity retention of 1600 mA h g−1 even after five days of exposure to dry air. This surface-modified Li x Si was successful in eliminating the irreversible capacity loss in the case of graphite, silicon, and Sn anodes. Previous studies employed costly materials such as Si, and the stability was limited to dry air. The same group developed an improved approach via one-pot metallurgical process for synthesizing Li x Si/Li2O composite using low-cost SiO/SiO2 as starting material [64]. Interestingly, the obtained composite consists of active Li x Si nanodomains embedded in the Li2O matrix, providing the excellent ambient air stability. The composite, when being added to various anode materials, could achieve a very high coulombic efficiency of >100% with excellent stability. The unique architecture of plum pudding helps in retaining the activity of Li x Si in the composite by minimizing the exposure to air, thereby improving the cycling performance. Remarkably, the synthesized composite itself can act as an anode material and have the potential to replace lithium anode for the next-generation batteries. To further improve the air stability of these materials, Zhao et al. developed a simple and effective strategy by encapsulating Li x M (M = Si, Sn, or Al) nanoparticles between large graphene sheets [65]. Freestanding Li x M/graphene foils were produced using this new method, which is capable of surviving in ambient air. Li x Si was used as an anode material, improving cycle performance with 98% retention after 400 cycles. These results suggest the importance of lithiated metal oxides (Li x M, where M = Si, Sn, Al, Ge) as a potential substitute for lithium metal anodes. Further, they extended the synthesis approach to group IV elements and their corresponding oxides, yielding Li22Z5 alloys and Li22Z5-Li2O composites (Z = Si, Ge, Sn, etc.) [30]. As-synthesized materials were used as a pre-lithiation agent with graphite and alloy-type anode materials which could improve the first cycle coulombic efficiency. Density functional theory (DFT) simulations were performed to understand the interaction between the constituents in the Li22Z5 (Z = Si, Ge, Sn) structure. Among all the materials, Li22Ge5 was the most thermally stable alloy with a binding energy of −2.98 eV (Si: −0.80 eV, Sn: −2.15 eV) with Li. Noteworthy to mention that the binding energies between O atoms (of Li2O) and surface Li atoms (of Li22Si5) are much larger than those between Li and Si atoms in the Li22Si5 structure, which helps to stabilize Li x Si in the Li x Si-Li2O composites. These unique Li22Z5-Li2O composites exhibited excellent ambient-air stability, which is well compactable with the current battery fabrication environment. The high capacity of Li x Si/Li2O and Li22Z5 (Z = Si, Ge, Sn) requires a small amount of additives to compensate for the irreversible capacity losses. Pre-lithiation additives such as Li22Z5 (Z = Si, Ge, Sn) can provide excess Li+ ions along with the formation of Si/Ge/Sn, which are electrochemically active, do not add any additional residues, and have no side reaction, making them potential pre-lithiation additives. 2.2 Cathode pre-lithiation additives During the first discharge, there is an irreversible loss of lithium from the cathode material during the formation of a SEI, resulting in a decreased capacity in the subsequent cycles. The irreversible capacity loss can range from 7%–20% for graphite anode and 30% for Si anode [66]. This irreversible capacity loss can be compensated by adding sacrificial salts to the cathodes, producing SEI on the anode during the first few cycles. Four critical parameters decide on the perfect cathode pre-lithiation additives [67,68]. • One of the most important criteria is that pre-lithiation additives should possess a high theoretical capacity so that a small quantity of additives can compensate the irreversible capacity loss. • The pre-lithiation additives should be able to provide the Li+ during the first charge process before reaching the maximum potential of the cathodes and should not accept the Li+ during the discharge. Thus, to be a potential cathode additive, the materials should have a lithiation potential below the minimum cathode discharge potential and de-lithiation potential below the maximum cathode charge potential. • The pre-lithiation additives should not hinder/deteriorate the performance of the cathode, and the by-products after the first cycle should not degrade the battery performance. • The addition of the pre-lithiation additives should be compatible with the current battery fabrication process without any additional processing steps. The following section discusses different cathode pre-lithiation additives and introduces the detailed research progress. 2.2.1 Li2NiO2 as cathode pre-lithiation additive One of the significant challenges in the battery community is the hazards of overcharging, which may result in the explosion of the device. To date, several efforts have been made to overcome this problem. Li2NiO2 has been reported to show a high charge capacity of 320 mA h g−1 and a discharge capacity of 240 mA h g−1 at the first cycle in the voltage window of 1.5–4.6 V (vs. Li/Li+), which makes it an efficient Li+ ions doner to compensate them for the initial capacity loss at the anode [69]. Lee et al. demonstrated that adding a small quantity of Li2NiO2 (4 wt%) additive offers a sophisticated way of over-discharge protection and could improve the first cycle coulombic efficiency without deteriorating the cathode characteristics [70]. This demonstrates that the pre-lithiation additive has advantages beyond compensating for the capacity loss and enhancing safety. Later, Kim et al. developed Li2NiO2 coated with Al2O3 as a highly air-stable cathode additive [71]. As a cathode material, it showed better reversible capacity in the voltage range from 4.3 to 1.5 V (26% capacity loss); but when the lower cut-off potential was raised to 2.5 V, a largely irreversible capacity loss (71% capacity loss) was observed, suggesting Li2NiO2@Al2O3 could help to overcome the irreversible capacity loss of LiCoO2/graphite system. Another advantage of using Li2NiO2@Al2O3 as an additive is that it can help in evading exothermic reaction on overcharging (12.0 V). With just 4 wt% of cathode additive, 100% coulombic efficiency could be obtained with an added safety feature on overcharging. 2.2.2 Li3N/LiN3 as cathode pre-lithiation additive Pre-lithiation additives (e.g., Li2O, LiF, and Li3N) have much higher theoretical capacities than Li-rich compounds and other sacrificial pre-lithiation additives. Among them, Li3N is an attractive cathode prelithiation material for LIBs, considering its high theoretical specific capacity (2309 mA h g−1) and low theoretical decomposition potential (∼0.44 V vs. Li+/Li). A large amount of Li can be extracted from Li3N (2Li3N → 6Li+ + N2↑) to offset the initial lithium loss during the initial extraction, which results in the evolution of N2 gas with no residual by-products. An initial investigation of the use of LiN3 as a potential pre-lithiation additive was carried out by Shanmukaraj et al. in 2010 [72]. They found that LiN3 can work as a sacrificial salt to compensate for the irreversible capacity loss (due to SEI formation), whose decomposition voltage lies within the 4.0 V cathodes (LiMn2O4, LiCoO2). Although LiN3 is stable in the air, its lower thermal decomposition (115 to 298 °C) could hamper the current battery manufacturing process, where the electrodes are dried at around 120 °C. Alternative to LiN3, Li3N possesses a significantly high theoretical capacity of 2308 mA h g−1, thus effectively mitigating the irreversible capacity loss with only little quantity of cathode pre-lithiation additive. The use of Li3N as a cathode additive was first demonstrated by Park et al., where they evaluated the effect of concentration on the electrochemical properties of LiCoO2 cathode [32]. One of the major advantages of using Li3N as an additive is that the decomposition of Li3N leads to the formation of N2 gas, which can be removed after the first cycle. Whereas in the case of Li3− x M x N (M = Transition metals), a trace amount of transition metals or respective nitrides remain, which amend the electrochemical performance of the cathodes. They also found that the electrochemical performance of Li3N mostly depends on its surface purity and particle size. The commercially obtained Li3N possesses a large particle size with inactive lithium oxide and carbonate on the surface, compromising the electrochemical performance compared to the smaller particle without surface poisoning. Nevertheless, although Li3N as an additive compensates for the initial consumed Li+ ions, it is insulating in nature, drastically affecting the rate performance when blended with the cathode material. Instead, a coating of Li3N on the cathode material was found to help compensate for initial Li+ loss without sacrificing the rate performance. Thus, using Li3N as a pre-lithiation additive has been proven to effectively minimize the dead volume in the cathode and increase cell capacities for a high-energy-density lithium-ion battery [32]. Nevertheless, Li3N suffers from poor chemical and environmental stability due to its high reactivity with moisture and incompatibility with the processing solvents used in electrode fabrication. To overcome this drawback, Sun et al. developed passivated Li3N by reacting lithium metal with nitrogen, followed by annealing [73]. This resulted in creating a dense layer of Li2O and Li2CO3, which acts as a protective coating that can improve the chemical and environmental stability in ambient conditions. Practical use of this passivated Li3N as a pre-lithiation additive was demonstrated by the controlled addition (2.5% and 5%) of Li3N to various cathodes such as LiCoO2 (LCO), LiNi0.6Co0.2Mn0.2O2 (NCM), and LiFePO4 (LFP) via traditional fabrication process. Interestingly, compared to pristine LCO, the LCO cathode with the addition of 2.5% and 5% Li3N additives obtained an extra capacity of 51 and 96 mA h g−1, respectively, during the first cycle without hampering the cyclic stability. Similar performance was also observed with other cathode materials such as NCM and LFP. This approach opens up new frontiers to develop universal pre-lithiation material for various cathode materials with better stability than the commercial fabrication process can easily adapt. In another approach, Bian et al. designed a Li2CO3 passivated Li3N via simple aging of the Li3N powder in a CO2 atmosphere [74]. The presence of Li2CO3 enabled the decomposition of Li3N at a higher potential due to the polarization of the electrode, which can be attributed to the insulating nature of Li2CO3. The Li3N (2 wt%) additives exhibited a dual role of acting as a pre-lithiation additive and an electrode stabilizer to improve the discharge capacity by ∼10% in an Li(Li0.18Ni0.15Co0.15Mn0.52)O2 (LLMO)/graphite full cell with excellent cycling stability. In fact, during the charge cycle, there is a formation of the Li2N intermediate. The Li2N reacts with LLMO and the electrolyte causing a smooth electrode surface and preventing the electrode from cracking and leaching, thus stabilizing the device. Recently, Yang et al. developed an improved pre-lithiation approach by the direct deposition of metallic lithium on cathode surface followed by fixing it by nitrogen gas to synthesize pure alpha-Li3N film with (001) plane perpendicular to cathode surface [75]. This innovative approach overcomes the use of volatile and toxic (THF) solvents during electrode preparation. On the other hand, introducing Li3N along with the cathodes or directly pressing the Li3N powder on the cathode results in the inaccurate control of the quantity, thickness, and homogeneity. With just 1% Li3N on the LFP cathode, LFP/graphite full cell showed improved initial discharge capacity, with the capacity retention rate enhancing from 59% to 77% after 120 cycles. This opens up new research opportunities to explore the direct deposition of pre-lithiation additives for anode-free metal batteries. 2.2.3 Other cathode pre-lithiation additives In another case, a novel Li6CoO4 was used as a cathode additive to compensate for the irreversible capacity loss in the LiCoO2//SiO x cell [76]. Li6CoO4 as a cathode material showed high charge capacity and poor discharge capacity. This excess lithium can be utilized as an additional source of lithium at the cathode since Li6CoO4 exhibits a lower operational voltage than LiCoO2. The first cycle performance was shown to be heavily influenced by the concentration of additives. It is believed that the capacity contribution of the additives increased the charge capacity of the cathodes to 133 mA h g−1 in full cell configuration, compared to the previous 77 mA h g−1 without additive. Adding Li6CoO4 acts as a sacrificial additive that helps compensate for the irreversible capacity loss at the anode. During the first discharge, a maximum of 0.6 mol Li+ was de-intercalated back to the cathode, allowing the maximum cathode utilization (Li0.9CoO2) in the subsequent cycles. The initial work on Li2MoO3 as a cathode material was carried out by James et al. in 1988; they observed large irreversibility due to the dissolution of Mo and slow reaction kinetics, which rules out the possible use of Li2MoO3 for rechargeable batteries [77]. Later in 2012, Park et al. investigated the use of Li2MoO3 as a potential cathode additive by forming a solid solution with LiFeO2, which can help suppress the Mo dissolution and stabilize the structure at charged states [78]. Li2MoO3 has a sloping discharge voltage of around 3.4 V, which can alter the voltage plateau of the cathode composite and control charge/discharge characteristic. The LiCoO2 cathode demonstrated the high-rate performance and increased cycle performance in the voltage range from 0.0 to 4.3 V (vs. graphite) with a capacity retention of 85.3% after 100 cycles with just 10 wt% 0.9 Li2MoO3-0.1 LiFeO2 additives. In another case, Su et al. investigated the use of Li5FeO4 (LFO) as a sacrificial additive at the cathodes to overcome the irreversible capacity loss [79]. When coupled with high voltage cathodes such as LiCoO2, an improved first cycle performance was observed with improved coulombic efficiency (>95%). This sacrificial salt compensates for the initial capacity loss and acts as an additional cathode lithium source. The use of Li5FeO4 as an additive was further explored to compensate for the high irreversible capacity loss of SiO anodes [80]. Li5FeO4, when added to LiNi0.5Co0.2Mn0.3O2 (NCM523) cathode, could improve lithium utilization to 22%. Interestingly the improved capacity retention from 90.94% to 98.93% was observed after 50 cycles. A significant drawback of employing Li5FeO4 as pre-lithiation additives is that certain residues (Fe) remain in the electrode on decomposition, negatively impacting overall cell performance. To overcome this drawback, Bie et al. demonstrated the Li2O2 (Li2O2 → 2Li+ + O2↑) as a potential pre-lithiation additive [81]. During the initial charging process, Li+ and O2 are expected to be released, of which Li+ can be utilized to compensate for the anode irreversibility and the formed O2 can be removed after the battery formation step. Another advantage is the compatibility with the traditional solvent and binders, making it suitable for the current battery fabrication process. Li2O2 decomposition occurs at high potentials, which requires a catalyst to reduce the charge voltages; thus, it could be an efficient pre-lithiation additive of NCM cathodes where NCM can act as both active material and the catalyst to decrease the potential of the cathodes. Using Li2O2 as a pre-lithiation additive could help compensate for the irreversible capacity loss of the graphite and silicon anodes. Recently, Wang et al. investigated the dual role of Li3P@rGO to compensate for the initial capacity with enhanced safety [82]. The decomposition of Li3P (Li3P → 3Li+ + P) occurs at 1.0 V with a high theoretical capacity of 1547.61 mA h g−1 and low lithiation potential. A low concentration (2.5%) of additive in LiFePO4 (LFP)//graphite full cell could improve the discharge capacity up to 10% compared to pristine LFP cathode. Interestingly, the by-products (phosphorus) on the cathode can act as a flame-retardant agent and improve safety. This opens up a new direction to investigate potential self-sacrificial salts that can improve the overall electrochemical performance in terms of safety and long-term cycling. 2.2.4 Transition metal/Li2X (X = O, F) composites as pre-lithiation additive Despite enormous progress on the cathode pre-lithiation additives, the effective compensation of the irreversible capacity loss is still limited by the low capacity and complicated synthesis approach. Earlier, Ali et al. demonstrated micro-sized Li2O as a lithium source at the high-capacity composite cathode to counter the first cycle irreversibility in the Si-based anode [83]. They further revealed that the oxidation of Li2O generated a series of Li x O y species (e.g. (Li2O)+, LiO, Li2O2, (Li2O2)+, LiO2. (LiO2)+, O2) during the first charge process. These Li x O y species accelerated the electrolyte decomposition and resulted in an interface film on the electrodes. With the addition of Li2O to high energy material (HEM, Li2MnO3-LiMO2), the charge capacity of 600 mA h g−1 was obtained at a high voltage of 4.45 V, suggesting the Li2O activation. They showed that the activation depends on the current rate, electrolyte salt, and anode type. Sun et al. developed a one-pot chemical reduction process for synthesizing metal/Li2O oxides via nanoscale mixing [84]. The synthesized M/Li2O nanocomposite possesses unique characteristics of significant potential hysteresis, which allows the easy extraction on charging and restricts the reversibility during the discharge, thus acting as a lithium reservoir with high specific capacity (724 mA h g−1 for Co/Li2O, 799 mA h g−1 for Fe/Li2O, 935 mA h g−1 for Mn/Li2O). The LiFePO4 cathode with the addition of 4.8% Co/Li2O additive showed an overall increase of 11% higher than pristine LiFePO4. In another case, Fe/Li2O was synthesized via a simple and economical in-situ solid-phase reaction method. It has excellent compatibility with the active materials, binder, and common solvents, which can easily adapt to the current battery manufacturing industries. As a cathode pre-lithiation additive, Fe/Li2O (7.5%) could improve the coulombic efficiency of LiNi0.6Co0.2Mn0.2O2 by 9.1% with the improved cyclic stability of 90.2% after 70 cycles [85]. Sun et al. proposed to use LiF/X (X = Fe, Co) nanocomposites as a potential pre-lithiation additive due to their rich lithium content and stability in the ambient atmosphere [86]. A simple chemical reaction of molten lithium and CoF3 powder was carried out in an Ar atmosphere to obtain LiF/Co consisting of ultrafine lithium fluoride and metal particles (∼5 nm) (Fig. 3a). The synthesized LiF/Co nanocomposites act as a rich lithium donor and are compatible with existing cathode materials. The initial charge capacity for the LiF/Co nanocomposites could reach up to 520 mA h g−1 with a discharge capacity of 4 mA h g−1 in the voltage range from 4.2 to 2.5 V, which suggests the high donor characteristics (514 mA h g−1). It was observed that the lithium intake in LiF/Co takes place below 2.2 V, far lower than the cut-off voltages of the existing cathodes. To demonstrate the practical application, 4.8% LiF/Co additive was combined with LFP cathodes, which showed an improved charge capacity (∼20% higher), suggesting high pre-lithiation efficiency. Using such an additive can help compensate for the irreversible capacity of high-capacity alloying-based anodes. Similarly, the same group explored the use of Li2S/M (M = Co, Fe) composite as an efficient pre-lithiation additive [33]. Fig. 3(b) shows the schematic of the chemical synthesis of Li2S/metal (e.g., Li2S/Co) composite and the electrochemical extraction of lithium during the battery charge process. The lower lithiation potential of metal sulfides makes them perfect pre-lithiation additives that do not allow the lithium to transform to its initial state. Similar to LiF/Co, Li2S/Co has a high lithium donor capacity of 670 mA h g−1 in the voltage window of existing cathodes. To overcome the high cost and toxicity of cobalt, LiF/Fe was also explored as efficient pre-lithiation additives with a high donor capacity of 480 mA h g−1. The simple fabrication process and potential compatibility with the cathodes make it an efficient strategy to overcome the irreversible capacity loss of the high-capacity anodes for the next-generation LIBs. Further, Du et al. developed Fe/LiF/Li2O ternary nanocomposites with high doner capacity (550 mA h g−1) and excellent stability [87]. Fig. 3(c) shows the mechanism for the chemical stability between Fe/LiF/Li2O and Fe/Li2O nanocomposites in the ambient air. Gibbs free energy calculation showed high resistance of LiF with H2O and CO2 compared to Li2O, making it stable in atmospheric conditions. During the first charge, a plateau was observed at 3.1 V along with a sloping voltage plateau between 3.8 to 4.1 V in the charge profile as shown in Fig. 4 (b). The lower voltage plateau (3.1 V) can be attributed to the conversion reaction of Fe/Li2O. Whereas, the upper voltage slope (3.8 to 4.1 V) can be attributed to the conversion reaction from Fe/LiF to FeF3. In the case of LiF/Li2O composite, a charge capacity of 6 mA h g−1 was obtained that can be attributed to the high decomposition of LiF and Li2O, which suggests that the presence of transition metals can help in lowering the lithium extraction voltage and changing the lithium-extraction reaction mechanism. Fig. 4(a–c) shows the initial charge-discharge profiles of Fe/LiF/Li2O and Fe/Li2O after storing in the ambient atmosphere (20% humidity) for different times, suggesting the better capacity retention in the presence of the LiF matrix. These pre-lithiation additives were used for various cathodes such as LiCoO2, LiFePO4, and LiNi1− xy Co x Mn y O2. With the mere addition of 4.8 wt% Fe/LiF/Li2O additive to the LiNi0.8Co0.1Mn0.1O2, a 15% improvement in charge capacity was achieved as compared to the pristine cathode. 2.2.5 Li2S-based cathode pre-lithiation additives Li2S has a theoretical capacity of 1167 mA h g−1 with an activation potential of 3.5 V, which is lower than the cut-off potentials of high voltage cathodes. Also, the lithiation of sulfur (S8) occurs below 2.4 V, below the cut-off potential of the existing cathodes, making it a potential pre-lithiation additive. Zhan et al. designed a core-shell Li2S/KB/PVP nanocomposite as a cathode pre-lithiation material [88]. In this work, the pre-lithiation slurry was prepared using the Li2S, Ketjenblack carbon black (KB), and poly(vinylpyrrolidone) (PVP) in an anhydrous ethanol medium under an inert atmosphere and coated on the LFP cathodes as shown in Fig. 5 (a). The LFP(Li2S) coupled with graphite showed the improved charge capacity (25 mA h g−1) and coulombic efficiency compared to pristine LFP/graphite full cell. Interestingly, the overall energy density was improved by 5.6% with pre-lithiation (Fig. 5d). The Si-C anodes undergo largely irreversible capacity loss of Li+ ions for forming SEI during the first cycle, which affects their coulombic efficiency. Li2S/KB/PVP nanocomposite was introduced to compensate for the irreversible capacity loss of the Si-C anodes [31]. Fig. 5(b and c) compares the voltage profiles with normalized capacity for LiFePO4 and the LiFePO4 (Li2S) half-cells with the Si-C half-cell. In the case of LiFePO4|Si-C, some active lithium is consumed due to the formation of the SEI layer on the surface of the Si-C anode, which results in the incomplete lithiation of LiFePO4. Pre-lithiation of LiFePO4 with Li2S can help compensate for the lithium loss by decomposition of Li2S. Fig. 5(e) compares the specific energy density for LiFePO4|Si-C and LiFePO4 (Li2S)|Si-C at different cycles. These results highlight the importance of pre-lithiation additives as sacrificial salts for achieving high energy density for the next-generation batteries. 3 Pre-sodiation additives Like Li-ion batteries, Na-ion batteries also suffer from irreversible capacity loss due to the formation of passivating SEI layer. However, finding a suitable anode material with high capacity and stability is challenging. Hard carbon-based materials have been extensively used as anode but suffer from poor coulombic efficiency. Various strategies have been proposed to address this issue, such as anode pre-sodiation, Na-rich cathode, and self-sacrifice cathode additives to counteract the permanent loss of Na+ by providing an additional supply of Na+ ions [89,90]. Using a self-sacrificial cathode additive is considered a viable option in terms of operational safety and compatibility with large-scale battery production. A potential pre-sodiation additive should possess a high gravimetric/volumetric capacity, high-capacity utilization, moderate decomposition potential, nontoxicity, thermal/chemical stability, easy operation, and low cost. Thus, using sacrificial salts/pre-sodiation additives plays a critical role in developing the next-generation batteries with high energy density and stability. This section will discuss the various pre-sodiation additives and their influence on full cell performance. Li2NiO2 had been studied as a potential candidate as a pre-lithiation additive for lithium-ion batteries. Professor Goodenough developed sodium analogue (Na2NiO2) as a sacrificial salt for Na-ion batteries in 2015 [91]. Although Na2NiO2 is unstable when in contact with moisture, it was found to be stable in a dry oxygen atmosphere. Electrochemical studies revealed a high charge capacity of 276 mA h g−1 and a discharge capacity of 88 mA h g−1 for Na2NiO2, suggesting its potential role as a sacrificial salt. Na2NiO2 undergoes an irreversible phase transition to layered NaNiO2 followed by a reversible Na+ insertion/extraction. To prove this, NaCrO2 cathode was tested with Sb/C anode with 10% substitution of Na2NiO2 additive, which showed an improved reversible capacity and coulombic efficiency. Similarly, sodium analog (Na3P) of Li3P additive was investigated as a positive electrodes reservoir to compensate for sodium loss [92]. When coupled with Na1[Fe0.5Mn0.5]O2 cathode, an extra energy storage density of 7% was obtained. Besides, NaN3 was investigated as a sacrificial salt with Na0.67[Fe0.5Mn0.5]O2 cathode material [36]. It was found that the concentration of additives played a crucial role in the overall electrochemical behavior. With the addition of 10% NaN3 to Na0.67[Fe0.5Mn0.5]O2//hard carbon (HC), the full cell could achieve a 60% increase in the reversible capacity without compromising the cycle life. Another innovative strategy for the in-situ formation of Na2CO3-Na x MO2 (x< 0.7, M transition metal) was developed by Tarascon et al., in which the Na2CO3 played a dual role of a sacrificial and stabilizing agent [38]. The decomposition of Na2CO3 can result in the gas (CO2) formation during the first cycle. Removing gases and other by-products that remain after the first production/formation cycle is a significant challenge. In another case, Jo et al. introduced NaNO2 as a cathode additive which acts as a sacrificial salt for Na2/3[Co0.05Mn0.95]O2 cathodes [93]. On electrochemical oxidation, NaNO2 is oxidized to Na+ ions and NO2; the produced by-product NO2 is an oxidizer that facilitates Na+ removal from Na2/3[Co0.05Mn0.95]O2 structure, which improves the initial charge capacity. The efficacy of the NaNO2 additive was demonstrated with Na2/3[Co0.05Mn0.95]O2//hard carbon full cell, which showed the first coulombic efficiency close to 100%. Shen et al. manipulated the irreversible phase transition of NaCrO2 towards an effective self-sacrificing sodium compensation additive for a stable SEI formation [94]. The irreversible phase transition could deliver an irreversible capacity of 230 mA h g−1 in the high voltage region. When the potential exceeds 3.9 V, the Na ion is extracted, which helps migrate the Cr ion into the vacant octahedral sites, resulting in the formation of non-electrochemically active-phase Na0.06CrO2. The excess Na+ ions are utilized in forming SEI film during the first cycle. Benefiting from this sacrificial salt, Na3V2O2(PO4)2F//hard carbon full cell showed the improved cyclability with the enhanced energy density from 122 to 201 Wh kg−1. For the very first time, organic-based sacrificial salts such as ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid tetrasodium salt (EDTA-4Na) [93] and diethylenetriamine penta-acetic acid salt (DTPA-5Na) [95] were introduced by Myung et al. These two organic additives were directly incorporated by blending with Na deficient cathodes Na0.67[Al0.05Mn0.95]O2 and Na0.44MnO2 cathodes, respectively. In the case of EDTA-4Na/Na0.67[Al0.05Mn0.95]O2//hard carbon full-cell, a reversible capacity was significantly improved (152 mA h g−1) with coulombic efficiency of 89%, which was higher than that in the absence of additives (51 mA h g−1). Fig. 6 (a) shows the first charge and discharge of Na0.67[Al0.05Mn0.95]O2 and EDTA-4Na (10 wt%)/Na0.67[Al0.05Mn0.95]O2 composite, revealing the electrochemical oxidation of the EDTA-4Na salt in the composite. EDTA-4Na undergoes oxidative decomposition to generate 4 Na+ ions and form C3N by-product which possesses conductive nature that can help improve the reversible capacity. Fig. 6(b) shows the better capacity retention for the composite electrodes. Similar behavior was observed in the presence of DTPA-5Na. The conductive nature of the C3N by-product was further confirmed by galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GIIT) measurement, which showed the improved diffusivity of Na+ ion after DTPA decomposition at 4.3 V (Fig. 6c). With the addition of the sacrificing salt (DTPA-5Na) to Na0.44MnO2, the charge capacity increased from ∼58 to ∼128 mA h g−1 with the better cycle stability (∼83%) (Fig. 6d). These results suggest the importance of low-cost organic-based sacrificial salts for high-performance metal ion (Li+/Na+) batteries. Fig. 7 shows the reaction mechanism and their de-lithiation potential for various pre-lithiation/sodiation additives. Armand et al. developed a water-soluble sacrificial salt (Na2C4O4) that eliminates the need for using any toxic solvents for laminate preparation, thus paving the way for greener electrode fabrication techniques [96]. Na2C4O4, when added with Na3(VO)2(PO4)2F cathode materials, undergoes oxidation/decomposition to give rise to Na+ ion and gas CO2 at a potential 3.6 V with an additional capacity contribution of 256 mA h g−1. Interestingly, in full cell (Na3(VO)2(PO4)2F//hard carbon anode), an almost 50% increase in initial capacity was observed in the presence of the additives as compared to the pristine. In another case, Fernández-Ropero et al. explored the commercial Na2C3O5 sodium salt as a highly efficient, cost-effective, and safe cathode sodiation additive with a potential of 4.0 V vs. Na+/Na and the theoretical capacity of 331 mA h g−1 [97]. Using Na2C3O5 could readily improve the specific capacity and capacity retention by forming a thin and stable interface on Na2/3Mn0.8Fe0.1Ti0.1O2 cathode. Marelli et al. introduced an organic, cheap, and environmentally friendly disodium rhodizonate (Na2C6O6) as a sacrificial salt in Na0.67Mn0.6Fe0.25Co0.15O2//hard carbon full cell device [98]. Although the decomposition of Na2C6O6 led to the improved specific capacity, its coulombic efficiency was drastically affected, which can be attributed to the decomposition products (cyclic oxocarbon C3O3 −2 dianion). Thus, the choice of the sacrificial salts must consider the formation of by-products and their effects on the overall electrochemical performance. Therefore, new effective strategies must be provided to solve the problem faced with cathode Na compensation additives. Commercial sodium citrate (SC) was recently proposed as a high-efficient, low-cost, environmentally friendly sacrificial additive that can compensate 97% Na+ ion with a high capacity of 312 mA h g−1 [99]. The decomposition of SC can release Na+ ion along with some residuals (1,1,2,2-ethenetetracarboxylic acid, C6H4O8) and gas by-products such as CO and H2, which can be removed during the initial formation cycles. With just the addition of 10% of additive, the Na3V2(PO4)2F3/rGO//hard carbon full cell demonstrated a significantly increased energy density of 28.9%. In another case, Na2O2 was investigated by Guo et al. as a potential sacrificial salt with a high charge capacity of 400 mA h g−1 and good chemical stability in a dry atmosphere [37]. The Na2O2 additive was spray coated on the as-prepared electrode, which helps control the uniform coating of the sacrificial salts compared to the conventional mixing process. As a further benefit, there are no by-products that have a detrimental influence on the device's cyclability. Fig. 8 shows the trend of crucial pre-lithiation/sodiation additives for lithium and sodium-ion batteries. 4 Perspective and conclusions Troubleshooting the initial capacity loss in Li/Na-ion batteries is highly important to boost the device energy and cycle life performance. This initial capacity loss can be mainly attributed to the formation of SEI, electrolyte decomposition, and trapping of Li+/Na+ in the electrodes, which result in the loss of active Li+/Na+. In this regard, the pre-lithiation/sodiation process is essential in compensating for the initial loss of Li+/Na+ ions, thus improving the coulombic efficiency and energy density. Among various pre-lithiation/sodiation strategies, using pre-lithiation/sodiation additives is the most promising approach considering their easy processibility and compatibility with the state-of-the-art manufacturing process. Although rapid progress has been made to achieve the practical implementation of pre-lithiation/sodiation additives, their stability and complex preparation process restrict their large-scale implementation. On the one hand, adding pre-lithiation/sodiation additives can induce some additional by-products (inactive residues), which may not participate in the electrochemical reaction and result in poor energy density. On the other hand, the de-lithiation/sodiation process at high voltages produces undesired gasses (N2, CO, or CO2), which pose additional safety issues. Advantages of pre-lithiation/sodiation additive strategy • The use of additive enhances the initial coulombic efficiency and maintains high discharge capacities of the batteries in the subsequent cycles. Thus, tasking the specific design of additives with high irreversible capacity, operating at a suitable potential with negligible residues and related adverse effect, and more importantly, compatibility with the current battery manufacturing process is the need of the hour to improve the battery energy density, reversibility, and cycle life. • The degree/capacity of pre-lithiation/sodiation contributed by additives can be carefully controlled by monitoring the additive amount. A suitably designed high-capacity additive requires only a meager quantity to compensate for the initial irreversible capacity loss caused by SEI formation and defect at the anode, and CEI formation and phase conversion at the cathode. • Theoretically, the pre-lithiation/sodiation additives strategy can be applied to any cathodes, making them more versatile. • Further, the simplicity of the additive strategy, which does not require any additional step in the cell manufacturing process, makes it economical, easily adaptable with the current battery manufacturing process, and possible for the scale-up production. Disadvantages of pre-lithiation/sodiation additive strategy • The decomposition of pre-lithiation/sodiation additives produces inactive residues/deadweight, which adversely affects the gravimetric capacity and energy density of batteries • Furthermore, the gas released from the decomposition reactions of pre-lithiation/sodiation additives also needs to be addressed. • Complex synthesis approaches and poor stability in the ambient atmosphere require a control atmosphere (i.e., oxygen/moisture-free glove box) which hinders the large-scale application. We believe that the pre-lithiation/sodiation additives approach could potentially be adopted by the current battery manufacturing industries. Particularly with high-capacity additives, where a limited amount of additive can compensate for the loss in the first few cycles resulting in the high energy density. So far, the explored pre-lithiation and pre-sodiation additives in different battery systems have been summarized in Tables S1 and S2, respectively. It is worth mentioning that the practical use of different pre-lithiation materials/methods is highly dependent on their cost and compatibility with the existing battery industry. In this regard, the pre-lithiation additives with good industry compatibility would have more chance for a practical and scalable application. Selection criteria of pre-lithiation/sodiation additives Pre-lithiation/sodiation can be applied at both the anodes and cathodes, depending on the potential of lithiation/sodiation and de-lithiation/de-sodiation, i.e., the additive should be able to release its stored Li ions below the maximum potential during charge; but it does not take in Li ions at the minimum potential of discharge for cathodes. Important points to be considered while developing new pre-lithiation/sodiation additives: (a) The pre-lithiation/sodium additives should possess high gravimetric and volumetric capacity which can compensate for the capacity loss with minimum quantity of additives. (b) Pre-lithiation/sodium additives should possess high irreversibility so as to avoid Li+/Na+ re-insertion after the first charge/discharge in the desired voltage window. (c) Adding pre-lithiation/sodiation additives should be easy and compatible with the current battery manufacturing process/dry air conditions (NMP solvent, current collector, and binder) and other battery components (active materials, electrolyte, and separator) without adding any processing cost. (d) The pre-lithiation/sodiation additives should not leave any trace of residues or release gas by-products after the first cycle, which can affect the electrochemical performance of the electrodes. (e) The controlled pre-lithiation/sodiation should avoid lithium/sodium plating or the formation of dead lithium at the electrode interface. So far, the use of pre-lithiation/sodiation additives has only focused on compensating for the irreversible capacity loss. Still, the possibilities to stabilize the SEI, improve rate properties, and stabilize Li/Na plating will be explored. The reactivity and poor air stability impede the scalability, which directs to improve the air stability with a scalable approach to adapt the battery manufacturing process. The environmental stability can be enhanced by surface modification of the pre-lithiation/sodiation via organic/inorganic coating to make it air-stable and compactible. Developing pre-lithiation/sodiation additives that do not leave behind any by-products is highly prioritized. Although major advances have been done on improving the pre-lithiation (donating) capacity of the pre-lithiation additives, their implementation in the practical lithium-ion batteries (pouch cell level) is overlooked. In-depth understanding the effect of pre-lithiation at the materials level and electrode level is needed in the future to be successfully practical implementation. Various in-situ and ex-situ techniques should be applied to further understand and obtain detailed information about the changes caused by pre-lithiation/sodiation additive for active materials. Further research on anode pre- sodiation additives should be developed (Na-Sn, Na-Sb, and Na-SnO x ). With the increasing demand for anode-free configuration in the last few years, the pre-lithiation/sodiation plays a critical role in providing additional Li+/Na+ reservoirs, thereby maximize the energy density of anode-free lithium/sodium battery systems. Pranav Kulkarni completed his doctoral work in physics from Jain (Deemed-to-be University), Bangalore in 2020. His doctoral research was focused on the development and understanding of electrode materials for energy storage applications such as lithium and sodium-ion batteries. Currently, he is working as a Brain Pool Fellow at Department of Energy Engineering, Gyeongsang National University, South Korea. His current research is focused on anode free metal batteries. Hyunyoung Jung is a principal investigator in the research laboratory of nanomaterials and energy systems at Gyeongsang National University. He received a Ph.D. in chemistry from Seoul National University in 2008 and was a research associate at Carnegie Mellon University in 2009 and Northeastern University from 2010 to 2015. He joined as a faculty member in the Department of Energy Engineering in 2015. He is a member of the Materials Research Society, European Materials Research Society, the Korean Electrochemical Society, the Korean Battery Society, the Korean Institute of Chemical Engineers, and the Materials Research Society of Korea. His research interests include synthesis and structure-property relations of nanostructures and nanocomposites, materials science and applications of nanomaterials, next-generation energy storage systems, and phase stability in nanoscale systems. Debasis Ghosh (PhD, IIT Kharagpur, 2014) has been working on electrochemical energy storage and conversion for more than a decade. Before joining as Assistant Professor at the Centre for Nano and Material Sciences, JAIN University, Bangalore in 2017, he was appointed as a postdoctoral fellow at KAIST in South Korea and at the University of Waterloo, Canada for a couple of years. He is also a visiting Professor (2022 onwards) at the Department of Energy Engineering, Gyeongsang National University, South Korea. The current research interest of his research group includes rechargeable batteries, supercapacitors, and designing multifunctional electrocatalysts for OER/ORR/HER applications. Mohammed Jalalah received his M.Sc from the University of Manchester, United Kingdom (UK), in 2009, and his Ph.D. from Hanyang University, Republic of Korea (ROK), in 2018. He is currently working as an Assistance Professor in the Department of Electrical Engineering and in the Promising Centre for Sensors and Electronic Devices (PCSED) at Najran University, Saudi Arabia. His research is focused on synthesizing and characterizing nanomaterials and quantum dots for energy, sensors, and catalysis applications. Mabkhoot Alsaiari received his PhD from University of Southampton, England in 2018. He is currently working as an Assistance Professor in the Department of Chemistry, Faculty of science and arts, and in the Advanced material and nanotechnology research center at Najran University, Saudi Arabia. He is also acting as the Vice Dean of Scientific Research at Najran University. His research activity is focused on surface chemistry, mining and materials science, chemical sensors, electrochemical sensors and photocatalysis. Farid A. Harraz received his BSc in chemistry (1991) and MSc in physical chemistry (1997), Cairo University, Egypt, the PhD from the School of Energy Science, Kyoto university, Japan in 2003. Currently he is a Professor at the Promising Centre for Sensors and Electronic Devices (PCSED), Advanced Materials and Nano-Research Centre, Najran University, Saudi Arabia. He has awarded Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS) Postdoc Fellowship during 2003-2005 and Federation of Arab Scientific Research CouncilsAward for Outstanding Scientific Research in Nanotechnology in 2014. His research area focuses on development of nanomaterials for sensors, energy and catalysis applications. Geetha Balakrishna is presently the Director of Centre for Nano and Material Sciences, JAIN University. Her current research interest focuses on perovskites, oxide/sulphide nanocrystals, and colloidal quantum dots, which are active towards photons and hence applicable in solar cells, water purification/disinfection/ desalination, and sensing technologies. She is a fellow member of many renowned scientific world bodies such as ACS, ANS, MRS, and Assoc of Haz Mater. She has been nominated as the regional coordinator of Global Materials Network (MRS body) from India and is the commission member of IUMRS. She holds many patents and has successfully completed many funded projects.

coredata.dc:description: Lithium/Sodium-ion batteries (LIB/SIB) have attracted enormous attention as a promising electrochemical energy storage system due to their high energy density and long cycle life. One of the major hurdles is the initial irreversible capacity loss during the first few cycles owing to forming the solid electrolyte interphase layer (SEI). This process consumes a profusion of lithium/sodium, which reduces the overall energy density and cycle life. Thus, a suitable approach to compensate for the irreversible capacity loss must be developed to improve the energy density and cycle life. Pre-lithiation/sodiation is a widely accepted process to compensate for the irreversible capacity loss during the initial cycles. Various strategies such as physical, chemical, and electrochemical pre-lithiation/sodiation have been explored; however, these approaches add an extra step to the current manufacturing process. Alternative to these strategies, pre-lithiation/sodiation additives have attracted enormous attention due to their easy adaptability and compatibility with the current battery manufacturing process. In this review, we consolidate recent developments and emphasize the importance of using pre-lithiation/sodiation additives (anode and cathode) to overcome the irreversible capacity loss during the initial cycles in lithium/sodium-ion batteries. This review also addresses the technical and scientific challenges of using pre-lithiation/sodiation additives and offers the insights to boost the energy density and cycle life with their possible commercial exploration. The most important prerequisites for designing effective pre-lithiation/sodiation additives have been explored and the future directions have been discussed.
